questions.question: A 35-year-old woman with severe rheumatoid arthritis has worsening joint pain, swelling, and stiffness despite taking methotrexate and an NSAID. The rheumatologist decides to add a corticosteroid to control inflammation. Which corticosteroid is the most appropriate, considering potency, duration, and side effects?
questions.explanation: intermediate potency and duration of action, making it a suitable choice for the long-term management of rheumatoid arthritis. It has potent anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects, which can help control this patient's joint inflammation and disease activity. Effects of corticosteroids on the body: Anti-inflammatory effects : It inhibits inflammatory mediators, such as prostaglandins and leukotrienes, and suppresses inflammatory cytokine production. Immunosuppressive effects : Inhibition of immune cell proliferation and function, including T-cells, B-cells, and macrophages Metabolic effects : Increased gluconeogenesis, lipolysis, and protein catabolism, leading to hyperglycemia, insulin resistance, and muscle wasting Mineralocorticoid effects : Promotion of sodium and water retention, potassium excretion, and blood pressure elevation (minimal in prednisone due to low mineralocorticoid activity). Duration of Action Glucocorticoid Potency Effects/Uses Short (8-12 hrs) Hydrocortisone (Option A) Low Physiological replacement therapy, adrenal insufficiency, anti-inflammatory Intermediate (12-36 hrs) Cortisone Anti-inflammatory, rheumatic disorders Prednisone Intermediate Anti-inflammatory, immunosuppressive, rheumatic disorders, asthma, autoimmune diseases. Prednisolone (Option C) Intermediate to Long Methylprednisolone Intermediate to High Anti-inflammatory, immunosuppressive, severe inflammatory conditions, multiple sclerosis. Long (36-72 hrs) Dexamethasone (Option D) High Anti-inflammatory, immunosuppressive, severe inflammatory conditions, cerebral edema. Betamethasone (Option B) Fludrocortisone Mineralocorticoid activity, adrenal insufficiency, salt-wasting disorders. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th Edition, Page 306-319

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman, pregnant with twins, is hospitalised at 30 weeks with PPROM. To reduce the risk of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in preterm infants, the obstetrician decides to administer corticosteroids. Which corticosteroid regimen is recommended to promote fetal lung maturity?

options.A: Betamethasone 12 mg IM every 24 hours for 2 doses
options.B: Dexamethasone 12 mg IM every 24 hours for 2 doses
options.C: Hydrocortisone 250 mg intravenous (IV) every 6 hours for 4 doses

questions.explanation: corticosteroid administration has significantly reduced the risk of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), and neonatal mortality in preterm infants. The optimal time for administration is between 24 hours and 7 days before delivery, allowing for sufficient time for the corticosteroids to stimulate surfactant production in the fetal lungs. The recommended corticosteroid regimen for promoting surfactant maturation in preterm pregnancies is Betamethasone 12 mg IM every 24 hours for a total of 2 doses. (OR) Dexamethasone 6 mg IM every 12 hours for a total of 4 doses (Option B) Betamethasone and Dexamethasone are the preferred corticosteroids due to their potency, minimal mineralocorticoid activity, and ability to cross the placenta effectively. Hydrocortisone (Option C) and Methylprednisolone (Option D) single dose are not recommended regimens for promoting surfactant maturation in preterm pregnancies. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th Edition, Page 309

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman with severe systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) involving multiple organs presents with fatigue, joint pain, skin rashes, and signs of lupus nephritis. The rheumatologist plans high-dose corticosteroids to induce remission. What is the preferred dose of corticosteroid?
questions.explanation: systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with multi-organ involvement, pulse therapy with high-dose intravenous corticosteroids is often used to induce remission and prevent further organ damage rapidly. The recommended regimen for Pulse therapy in this case would be methylprednisolone 1 gm intravenous (IV) daily for 3 consecutive days. This high-dose, short-term corticosteroid therapy aims to suppress autoimmune inflammation and prevent further organ damage quickly. Potential adverse effects associated with pulse therapy include hypertension, electrolyte imbalances (particularly hypokalemia), hyperglycemia, and an increased risk of infections. Close monitoring of blood pressure, electrolytes, and glucose levels is essential during and after pulse therapy. Adverse effects of Corticosteroids: Corticosteroids Adverse Effects Hydrocortisone (Option D) Adrenal suppression, increased risk of infections, fluid retention, hypertension. Cortisone Prednisone (Option A) Weight gain, osteoporosis, diabetes mellitus, cushingoid features, skin changes. Prednisolone Methylprednisolone (Option B) Hypertension, hyperglycemia, electrolyte imbalances (hypokalemia), psychiatric disturbances Dexamethasone (Option C) Psychiatric disturbances, cushingoid features, increased risk of infections. Betamethasone Fludrocortisone Hypertension, edema, hypokalemia. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th Edition, Page 317

Suspecting atopic dermatitis, the dermatologist prescribes a more potent topical steroid. Which topical steroid is most appropriate for this patient's condition and age?
questions.explanation: mid-potency topical corticosteroid that would be an appropriate choice for treating this pediatric patient's widespread and moderately severe atopic dermatitis. Triamcinolone (Option B) 0.025% - 0.1% cream/ointment Moderate Atopic dermatitis, contact dermatitis, psoriasis. Betamethasone (Option C) 0.05% - 0.1% cream/ointment High Severe inflammatory skin conditions, refractory cases. Fluocinolone 0.025% - 0.2% cream/ointment Moderate-high Atopic dermatitis, psoriasis, lichen planus. questions.question: A 62-year-old man with type 2 diabetes and hypertension presents with severe nausea, vomiting, muscle cramps, fatigue, dizziness, dehydration, and blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. Labs show hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis. Which medication is most appropriate for his condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Hydrocortisone Explanation: The patient's hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis are likely due to a lack of mineralocorticoid activity, resulting in impaired sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the kidneys. The clinical presentation and investigations indicate adrenal insufficiency, particularly mineralocorticoid deficiency. Hydrocortisone, a synthetic glucocorticoid, has both glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid effects. Hence, it is the drug of choice in acute adrenal insufficiency. It can substitute for deficient endogenous cortisol, which maintains homeostasis. The recommended dose is 10-12 mg/m2/day, with an initial bolus of 100 mg followed by 200mg over 24 hours. Fludrocortisone (Option B) , a mineralocorticoid that can replace deficient aldosterone. It is also used in adrenal insufficiency, but synthetic cortisol must be given in acute emergency settings when hemodynamic instability occurs. Spironolactone (Option C) is an aldosterone receptor antagonist used in treating hyperaldosteronism and heart failure but not appropriate for mineralocorticoid deficiency. Dexamethasone (Option D) is a potent, long-acting synthetic glucocorticoid. However, it has only a glucocorticoid effect and no mineralocorticoid effect, so it is not the first-line agent. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th Edition, Page 314

questions.question: Which of the following is Diethylstilbestrol (DES) classified as?
questions.explanation: and nonsteroidal estrogen. Classification of estrogens: Natural Estrogens Steroidal Synthetic Estrogens Nonsteroidal Synthetic Estrogens Estradiol Estrone Estriol Ethinylestradiol Mestranol Tibolone Diethylstilbestrol Hexestrol Dienestrol Effects of Estrogen: Aspect Effect of Estrogen Reproductive Organ Regulation Governs growth and function of female reproductive organs and menstrual cycles. Secondary Sexual Characteristics Prompts development of female secondary sexual characteristics during puberty. Bone Density Maintenance It helps maintain bone density by inhibiting bone breakdown and promoting bone formation. Cardiovascular It improves cardiovascular health by regulating cholesterol levels. Brain Function Influences cognitive function, memory, mood regulation, and emotional well-being. Skin and Hair Health Contributes to skin thickness, elasticity, hydration, and hair growth. Urinary Tract Integrity It supports the integrity of urinary tract tissues and may prevent urinary incontinence. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th Edition, Page 330

questions.question: A 54-year-old woman presents with a history of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer. She is prescribed tamoxifen as part of her adjuvant therapy regimen to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of tamoxifen?

options.A: It acts as a direct agonist on estrogen receptors in breast tissue.
options.B: It acts as an antagonist on estrogen receptors in breast tissue.
options.D: It stimulates progesterone receptors in breast tissue.

questions.explanation: Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM), acts as an antagonist on estrogen receptors in breast tissue. Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulators (SERMs) selectively target estrogen receptors in different tissues. Aspect Tamoxifen Raloxifene Mechanism of Action Estrogen Receptor (ER) Antagonist ↓ Binds to ER ↓ Tissue-specific effects such as : Antagonist in breast tissue (prevents estrogen binding). Agonist in bone and cardiovascular tissues (estrogen-like effects) Clinical Use Drug of choice for ER-positive breast cancer. Decrease the risk of contralateral breast cancer. Prevention of breast cancer. Treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis. Side Effects Increased risk of endometrial cancer. Thromboembolism, hot flashes, depression, hepatotoxicity, cataracts. No increased risk of endometrial cancer. Hot flashes, depression. Thromboembolism are seen Drug Interactions It should not be combined with fluoxetine and other SSRIs. SSRIs inhibit the CYP2D6 enzyme, essential for converting tamoxifen into its active form, endoxifen. This interaction may lower endoxifen levels, diminishing tamoxifen's effectiveness against estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. No significant drug interactions. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th Edition, Page 338

questions.question: A 32-year-old female presents with infertility. She has irregular menstrual cycles and is suspected of having anovulation. She was started on Clomiphene citrate. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?

options.A: Binds to estrogen receptors, exerting agonistic effects in breast tissues.
options.B: Acts as a SERM, exerting antagonist effects in the pituitary.
options.C: Inhibits aromatase enzyme activity, reducing estrogen synthesis.
options.D: Stimulates gonadotropin secretion by blocking estrogenic feedback inhibition of the pituitary.

questions.explanation: the pituitary. pituitary. Explanation: Aspect Clomiphene Citrate Mechanism of Action Blocking of estrogen receptors in hypothalamus by Clomiphene citrate ↓ Removal of estrogen feedback inhibition ↓ Increased GnRH secretion from the hypothalamus ↓ Increased FSH and LH secretion from the pituitary ↓ Stimulation of ovarian follicle growth ↓ Ovulation Uses Treatment of infertility due to failure of ovulation, often in cases of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) or unexplained infertility. Used in assisted reproductive technology (ART) procedures. Treatment of oligozoospermia in men, where it increases gonadotropin secretion, promoting spermatogenesis and testosterone secretion. Adverse Effects Polycystic ovaries Multiple pregnancies Hot flashes Vertigo Allergic dermatitis Increased risk of ovarian tumour Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th Edition, Page 336

questions.explanation: Aromatase enzyme in estrogen synthesis. Clomiphene (Option A) Blocks Estrogen Receptors in the Hypothalamus ↓ Prevents Negative Feedback Inhibition ↓ Increased Release of Gonadotropins (FSH and LH) from Pituitary ↓ Stimulation of Ovulation Ovulation induction. Fulvestrant (Option D) Binding to Estrogen Receptors (ER) ↓ ER Degradation and Downregulation ↓ Inhibition of ER Signaling Pathways ↓ Decreased Estrogen Advanced breast cancer treatment. Injection site reactions, nausea, liver impairment. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th Edition, Page 339

questions.question: Which progestin type is characterized by both estrogenic and androgenic actions?
questions.explanation: derivatives group, which includes compounds with weak estrogenic, androgenic, anabolic, and potent antiovulatory actions. Progestins: Drug Actions Side Effects Medroxyprogesterone acetate No significant estrogenic activity. Nausea, breast tenderness, menstrual changes, headache, abdominal pain, fatigue, dizziness. Levonorgestrel Has minimal estrogenic activity. Norethindrone Exhibits weak estrogenic and androgenic activity. Similar to medroxyprogesterone acetate, but with the addition of possible androgenic side effects such as acne, hirsutism, and changes in libido. Cyproterone Has antiandrogenic activity: Blocks androgen receptors and inhibits testosterone production. Menstrual changes, breast tenderness, weight changes, mood changes, decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, depression (rare but severe). Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th Edition, Page 341

questions.question: A 28-year-old man comes to the dermatologist with complaints of progressive thinning of hair for 3 years. His family has a history of male-pattern baldness. A diagnosis of androgenic alopecia was made, for which he was prescribed topical Minoxidil. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?

options.A: Blockade of 5 alpha-reductase enzyme, thus preventing DHT formation.
options.B: Ornithine decarboxylase enzyme inhibitor, which is found in the hair follicles.
options.C: Blockade of androgenic receptors along with progestational activity.
options.D: K+ channel opening leads to vasodilation of microvessels around the hair follicles.

questions.explanation: follicles. It acts by opening the K+ channel on the vascular smooth muscle of microvessels near the hair follicle, thus promoting hair growth . Adverse effects: Local irritation, burning sensation, and itching Rarely palpitation and dizziness occur Oral form can lead to hirsutism in females Options Description Finasteride/Dutasteride (Option A) MOA 5 α reductase enzyme inhibitor, which prevents the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. Uses Benign prostatic hyperplasia. Androgenic alopecia (oral form and not topical as a topical agent) Eflornithine (Option B) MOA It inhibits the ornithine decarboxylase enzyme found in the hair follicle, thus slowing hair growth and serving as a hair depilator. Uses Topical agent to remove excessive facial hair in Hirsutism in females, Cyproterone acetate (Option C) MOA The weak blocker of androgenic receptors with progestational activity. It also suppresses LH secretion. Uses Female hirsutism. Precocious puberty in boys. Inappropriate sexual behavior in men. Oral contraception in combination with ethinylestradiol. questions.question: A 56-year-old woman complains of hot flashes that interfere with her daily activities and sleep. Considering her history of recurrent thromboembolism, which of the following drugs would be appropriate for the treatment of her post-menopausal hot flashes?
questions.explanation: regulates mood and other functions. It reduces hot flashes by influencing thermoregulatory pathways in the hypothalamus. It is particularly suitable for women unable to use hormone replacement therapy. It is preferred over clonidine for treating hot flashes due to fewer side effects. Hormone replacement therapy with estrogen(Option A) It is the first-line treatment for managing hot flashes in postmenopausal women. Effective for controlling symptoms like hot flashes, body aches, and vaginal dryness. Used to prevent postmenopausal osteoporosis, fractures, and cardiovascular events. Contraindicated in : History of breast cancer or current breast cancer. History of endometrial cancer. History of recurrent thromboembolism due to increased risk of thromboembolic events. Clonidine(Option B) Clonidine, an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist, reduces sympathetic outflow to alleviate hot flashes by affecting the hypothalamus. It serves as a non-hormonal alternative for women unable to use estrogen, especially those with a history of hormone-sensitive breast cancers or recurrent thromboembolism. It is generally less effective than hormonal therapies and some non-hormonal options like SSRIs. Due to its side effects, including dry mouth, drowsiness, and hypotension, SSRIs like paroxetine are often preferred for their better tolerability and efficacy. Bazedoxifene(Option D) Bazedoxifene, a selective estrogen receptor modulator, manages osteoporosis in postmenopausal women but may induce hot flashes in some cases. It is contraindicated in patients with a history of recurrent thromboembolism due to thromboembolic risk. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th Edition, Page 334-335. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK585122/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4476484/#:~:text =Paroxetine%20(hydrochloride%20and%20mesylate)%20has,reductions%20in%20hot%20flash%20severity .

questions.question: A 48-year-old man comes to the OPD due to his inability to maintain a penile erection during sexual intercourse. He was prescribed Sildenafil to help with his erectile dysfunction. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?

options.A: Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-5 enzyme, thus increasing cytosolic cGMP levels.
options.B: Central alpha-2 agonist, reducing sympathetic outflow and causing vasodilation.
options.C: Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-3 enzyme, thus increasing cytosolic cAMP levels.
options.D: Peripheral alpha-blocker reduces vascular resistance and improve blood flow.

questions.explanation: levels. of action: Sildenafil ↓ Inhibits phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) enzyme ↓ Prevents cGMP degradation ↓ Increases cytosolic cGMP levels ↓ Prolongs activation of GMP-dependent protein kinase ↓ Inhibits myosin light chain kinase dephosphorylation ↓ Smooth muscle relaxation in the corpus cavernosum ↓ Increased blood flow ↓ Sustained penile erection Other uses: Pulmonary artery hypertension Side effects: Blue-green colour blindness Non Arteritic ischaemic optic neuropathy (NA ION) Priapism Flushing Nasal congestion Dyspepsia Hypotension Central alpha-2 agonist, reducing sympathetic outflow and causing vasodilation.(Option B) This mechanism is exhibited by Clonidine, which reduces blood pressure in hypertension, but it is not used due to the risk of withdrawal hypertension. Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-3 enzyme, thus increasing cytosolic cAMP levels.(Option C) Drugs acting by this mechanism include Amrinone , M ilrinone (used as inotrope in heart failure), and Cilostazol (used in Peripheral vascular disease.) Peripheral alpha-blocker reduces vascular resistance and improves blood flow(Option D) Phentolamine acts by this mechanism, which is helpful in the intraoperative management of pheochromocytoma and hypertension control in clonidine withdrawal and cheese reaction. Reference: K D Tripathi, Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th Edition, Page 155,327-328,601-602,611-612
